subject: Re: Way/Why
msgSnippet: Hi Lauren No-- wh isn t always used before why. How you write it is supposed to depend on *your* accent. British speakers would write their words differently
messageBody:
Hi Lauren

No-- 'wh' isn't always used before why. How you write it is supposed to depend on *your* accent. British speakers would write their words differently than, say, someone from ohio. You should write the lettering the way that you phonetically pronounce it when you speak.

As for "Ay" and "iy", I think of "iy" as looking more like an eye and ay as looking more like a curved leaf holding a pea. I don't know if that helps at all, that's just the way I think of it.

Also, in most cases you don't have to distinguish awe from ah from "ox". Those three symbols look visually similar for a reason. It's so that when you're writing you can just sort of blur them together and people will still know how to pronounce what you wrote.

Kathy

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "leaves_or" <leaves_or@...> wrote:
>
> I sought out this group because I was having a hard time distinguishing Awe-Ah-Ox. It's gratifying to see that I'm not the only one with that problem. (I'm California-born and Seattle-raised, so no wonder).
>
> I have a similar problem distinguishing Why from Way. Is this also characteristic of the western USA? Is the letter combination "wh" always written with Why? Are there any other cases that you would use it? For me, "wine" and "whine" or "weather" and "whether" are homophones.
>
> Since I'm learning Quickscript for personal use, it doesn't make much difference, I was just curious.
>
> Lauren
>
